So, whin the dare crater gave a marriage hint, why, I told her a dale of boiſter, conſarning an old croſs fadther, and being under age, and that I could not marry theſe three months. For, you know, one does not ſtand for a good double handful of oaths, and lies, whin one wants to ruin a ſweet, kind, angel, that one loves.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—Suppoſe you were to make a ſham marriage.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: A ſham marriage?—Faidth, and I would make that, if there were not a parcel of low raſcals, that make halters.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Pſhaw! That's a paltry, mechanical, fear.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But, you—you were telling me, you know, of—a—ſcheme—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Oh! The contract.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ay, faidth! The contract. You ſaid you would ſhew it me.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I will—I have brought it for that purpoſe [feeling for his pocket-book]. I, lately, found it an efficacious expedient.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And ſucciſsful?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Would have been, but for an unlucky accident.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But there is one ſmall impidimint.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Weſtminſter hall.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Baw! A houſe of cards.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh, and that it is; for 'tis ſupported by knaves, and full of tricks.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Here—here is the very contract I myſelf gave.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ay! [endeavouring to conceal her eagerneſs.]

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: And here a counterfeit copy, with a few ſlight, but eſſential, alterations.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I underſtand—To put the change upon her. [with an anxious eye, continually, toward the contract.]

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Which you may eaſily take, or make, an opportunity to do.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: [with affected indifference] Will, thin, lind them both to me; and, faidth, you ſhall ſee fine divarſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No—I—I'll have them copied for you. This is ſigned, and ſealed

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Arrah, what of that?—Ha! ha! ha! Sure, you are not afraid you would be obliged to marry a man?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No—The only danger, in truſting them to you, is that of loſing them. And, even then, there could be no ill conſequence; except by falling into the hands of one who is far enough from London.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ay, ay, lit me have them—I give you my honour to make a proper uſe of them.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You are a promiſing youth, and it would be a pity ſuch talents ſhould be baulked—So, here—here.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Promiſing? Oh, faidth, and I hope to ſurpriſe even you, yourſilf. You ſhall priſently hear of the ſucciſs of your ſchaimes.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [looking after Harriet] There a' goes—Hop, ſtep, and jump!— (Pauſe)—Ecod, ſhe does it featly!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: She! What's that you ſay?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: How a' ſkipp'd into the carriage!—There! Off it drives! Whur-r-r-r! Rattling away!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What does the fellow mean?—S'death!—Sure!—Who are you talking of?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why, of that Iriſh, gentleman-like, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Lady!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I wur coming ſtraight to tell you—There is a plot, mun, againſt you!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: A plot! [runs toward the door.]

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, you are too late!—A's gone!—Three ſtreets off by this.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees—She means to breed a confuſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Miſs Harriet.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Harriet!—By heavens 'tis ſhe!—

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees—'tis ſhe.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Secure fool! Ineffable ideot!—And, yet, in that diſguiſe, Lucifer himſelf could not have diſcovered her!—And who told you?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why, his worſhip's gentleman, Mr. Lapelle—A' o'erheard her tell my Lord aw her plot.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What courſe ſhall I take?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Suppoſe I wur to watch, and, when ſhe comes back, let your worſhip know?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Do ſo—But be very careful—And be very ſecret.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees, ees; I remember the place, mun.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Away—be watchful and be rewarded.

div.head: SCENE VI. SIR FREDERIC.
div.p: This is a thunder ſtroke!—Lord Morden in the plot, too!—It will come to Lady Morden's ears, I ſhall be blown, all my plans diſconcerted, myſelf laughed at, and my reputation eternally ruined!— [walks about] Ha!—There is one way to prevent the miſchief, yet—By heavens, it cannot fail!—I will go to Lady Morden, and, with feigned penitence, tell her every circumſtance, myſelf; only making her believe I knew Harriet, when I returned the contract. She wiſt admire my candour, think my contrition real▪ and thus will I turn this ſeeming diſaſter to excellent account, by making it an additional proof of ſincerity, and affection for her Ladyſhip!—Dear Wit, I thank thee; thou never forſakeſt me at a criſis!—Indeed!—My Lord! And my young Lady!—Ah, ha!—But you ſhall find one, perhaps, who can plot, as deeply as yourſelves.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: INTO what an abyſs of evils have I plunged, through inexperience, want of reflection, and an abſurd imitation of faſhionable follies!—Lapelle.

sp.speaker: Lapelle.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Is the young—young gentleman returned?

sp.speaker: Lapelle.
sp.p: [ſignificantly] No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I am on the rack!—The liberties in which Lady Morden permits this Sir Frederic are inſupportable!—Unable to be ſilent, and aſhamed to complain, I am tortured, by contending paſſions.—Lapelle—Let me know the inſtant—the—the young gentleman comes back.

sp.speaker: Lapelle.
sp.p: [going] Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Stay— [to himſelf] What if I were to inform Lady Morden of this affair?—Surely, ſhe could not ſhut her eyes againſt ſuch a palpable, ſuch an unprincipled, attempt at ſeduction!— [aloud] Go, and tell your Lady, I beg to ſpeak with her, a moment.

div.head: SCENE II. LORD MORDEN.
div.p: What an abſurd being is man!—Not a fortnight ago, Lady Morden was totally indifferent to me; and, now I am in danger of loſing her, I find I love her—To diſtraction love her!—Yet to ſink into a civil, ſober, domeſtic, man—To become the ſtanding jeſt of all thoſe highſpirited companions whoſe ſociety I have courted, whoſe maxims I have pretended to admire!—

div.head: SCENE III. LORD MORDEN, LADY MORDEN.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: So, my Lord, in melancholy contemplation; and at home, too!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Lud! I wonder how your Lordſhip can endure home! Of all places, in the world, home is, certainly, the moſt diſagreeable.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Did not your Ladyſhip meet Lapelle?

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Lapelle! no.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I—I wiſhed to ſee your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: To ſee me! What can your Lordſhip poſſibly want with me?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: To ſpeak to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Speak to me!—You perfectly ſurpriſe me.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: On a ſubject which—I—I ſcarcely know how to begin.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! What can have made your Lordſhip ſo ſerious? Ha! ha! ha!
I declare, I never ſaw you look ſo grave before!—This muſt be ſome very important ſecret, that can occaſion your Lordſhip to look ſo very diſmal!—I vow, I am quite impatient—Come, my Lord—Why don't you proceed?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I—I begin to find—I have been very fooliſh.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Is that the ſecret?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I—I feel I have been to blame.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: To blame, my Lord! How? Which way?—Or, if you have, how does it concern me?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip uſed to think our intereſts inſeparable.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: For which your Lordſhip always laughed at me. And, I freely own, I was a very ſilly—out of the way woman.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Perhaps not, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: How, my Lord!—Not?—Your Lordſhip is very polite, but you know very well I was.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Lady Morden, you once loved me—You yourſelf, not long ſince, kindly owned you did.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Very true, my Lord; but why—why now ſhould you reproach me with my follies?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I feel the ſeverity of your reproof—It is no more than I merit!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [with affected ſurpriſe] I, really, don't underſtand your Lordſhip!—I—I meant no reproof—We loved each other as long as it was agreeable to us, and, if my paſſion happened to out-laſt your Lordſhip's, that was none of your fault. Theſe are the principles of—of all rational people, you know, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: They are principles, madam, that, from my ſoul, I wiſh I had never heard!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Upon my honour, you aſtoniſh me!—Have not I learnt them from you, yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Unjuſtifiable, madam, as my conduct may have been, I never carried them to the ſame exceſs as Sir Frederic Faſhion.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [with an air of pique] Sir Frederic Faſhion may, perhaps, be as capable 〈◊〉 reformation as your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip may—may 〈◊〉 partial.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Partial!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Who ſo great a libertine as 〈◊〉 Sir Frederic?

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Has been—He has 〈◊〉 enough to confeſs it.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Has been!—Madam, 〈◊〉 exiſts a preſent proof of deliberate ſeduction!—An injured Lady!—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [ſmiling] Oh! What the— 〈◊〉 the Croat.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p:
What's your ſurpriſe, my Lo ••
▪ Don't I tell you he has confeſſed all his follie •
〈◊〉 me?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: But, madam, did he menti •• the contract?

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p:
To be ſure! And the— 〈◊〉 counterfeit copy—With the generous manne •
〈◊〉 which he, juſt now, returned Harriet the origin ••
▪ though ſhe thought he did not know her.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p:
I am petrified!—Lady M ••
den—I perceive, I have loſt your affections.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: My Lord—I am above diſſimulation. Yes—I own I have a paſſion, too permanent to be ſhaken; and the ſatisfaction of a ſelf-aſſurance that he who, at preſent, poſſeſſes my heart, will not, ſo ſoon, be weary of me, as he who had it before.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: You cut me to the ſoul!—Did you know what I feel!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Feel, my Lord! Ha, ha, ha! Oh fie!—Your Lordſhip is a man of faſhion, not of feeling.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Hovering miſchief, madam, has quickened benumbed nature in me. [kneels and takes her hand] Oh! let me conjure you, Lady Morden, to reflect on your preſent ſituation! I have conducted you to the horrid precipice of guilt, and deſtruction! Oh ſuffer me to ſave, to ſnatch, you from danger!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

div.head: SCENE IV. LORD MORDEN, LADY MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! How now, my Lord! Ha, ha, ha! Making love to your wife?

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Oh! Sir Frederic, if you had but come a little ſooner, you would have heard the moſt delightful morality!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Morality from my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, morality from my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Nay, I aſſure you, he is quite ſerious. [retires coquetting with Sir Frederic.]

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Rejected! Ridiculed! Deſpiſed! Their ſport! Their ſcorn!—Their ſubject for open ſarcaſm, laughter, and contempt! Oh! Inſupportable. [Lord Morden retires into his own room.]

div.head: SCENE V. LADY MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! My Lord has a mind to fall in love with me, once more.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Nobody, but my Lord, madam, would ever have ceaſed, a moment, to love you!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Well, Sir Frederic, and may I, then, at laſt, flatter myſelf I have found that ſympathy of ſoul, for which I ſo long have ſighed?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Alas, madam, I dare not rank myſelf your equal!—No, I dare not!—There is ſuch infinitude of perfection in your every thought, look, and expreſſion, that to merit you were to be, as you are, ſomething celeſtial!—Yet, ſuch virtue as mere humanity may arrive at, I will exhauſt nature with endeavours, and weary heaven with prayers, to acquire!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: There is, ſurely, ſome ſecret charm in your words.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p:
Did I think the gratification of any ſiniſter paſſion influenced my preſent conduct; were it not my hope to remove you from the cold embrace of ſatiated apathy, to the ſwee and endleſs tranſports of love, founded on, permit me to ſay, on a congeniality of ſoul and ſenriment; did I not feel an innate conviction that there, already, ſubſiſts, between us, a tie of the moſt indiſſoluble nature, an immaculate tie, a
marriage of the mind, ſuperior infinitely to all human inſtitutions; did I not think, and feel, thus, I would, inſtantly, dreadful as the image is 〈◊〉 thought, renounce that heaven which I have had the preſumption to contemplate, nay aſpire to poſſeſs!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: And if, after all this, you ſhould prove falſe, Sir Frederic!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Falſe, madam!—Oh! Let me conjure you to inflict any puniſhment on me, rather than that of ſuſpecting my ſincerity!—Thus, •• eeling, on this angelic hand, I vow—

div.head: SCENE VI. LADY MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC, LORD MORDEN.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I cannot reſiſt the impulſe which—How!—Sir Frederic!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p:
[riſing] My Lord. [with per
•••• indifference.]

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: So, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: So, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: You can liſten to morality from ••• ers, madam, if not from me!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Oh! I—I have no diſlike to a ••• non, when I—admire the preacher.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Madam—If you have no reſpect 〈◊〉 my honour, you might have ſome for my feelings, and—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p:
[interrupting him] A, a—Hold, •• ld, my Lord—You are beginning your diſ
•••• ſe again; but I am in a hurry, and will hear 〈◊〉 draw your concluſions ſome other opportu
••••
▪

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Nay, I will, upon my honour.

div.head: SCENE VII. LORD MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; a word with you, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: With me, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: With you.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Willingly. Your Lordſhip ſeems in ſo pleaſant a humour—

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Sir, I am in a humour neither to be trifled with nor ſneered at.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I can aſſure your, Ha, ha, ha! your Lordſhip, no man is happier to ſee you in your preſent temper than I am.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Look you, Sir Frederic, you and I have been too long of the ſame ſchool for me to be ignorant of your principles. But I begin to deteſt them!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: They are now, at this very moment, rending my heart. They have planted a neſt of adders in my boſom.—In ſhort, Sir—You muſt forbear your viſits to Lady Morden.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I am ſerious—determined.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! When her Ladyſhip gives me this advice, it may—perhaps—be followed.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: It muſt and ſhall be followed, Sir, when I give it.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Ridiculous as it may appear, to you, and ſuch as you, I feel, and will aſſert, a huſband's rights.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! I congratulate your
Lordſhip, on the keenneſs, and delicacy, of your feelings; they give me great pleaſure; infinite pleaſure, upon my ſoul. Ha, ha, ha!—As to—a huſband's rights, I—have no doubt, you will—very ſhortly—be in full poſſeſſion of them all.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Sir, I will have you know, I am, at preſent, in full poſſeſſion of them all.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: May be ſo, egad!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: And can no longer forbear telling you, I believe you to be a villain.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ah, now, your Lordſhip is perfectly explicit. [draw and fight.]

div.head: SCENE VIII. LORD MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC, GABRIEL, who runs fearleſs between them, and looks firſt at one, then at the other.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: How now, ſirrah! How dare you take this liberty?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, ecod, there do ſeem to be ſome danger in it; an I had not dared to dare, but that I thought that your Lordſhip wou'd na ſtick I.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Be gone, ſirrah!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, but my Lady ſent me, and would be glad to ſpeak wi' your honour's worſhip.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: With me?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh no! Not wi' your Lordſhip's honour's worſhip; but wi' his worſhip's honour, Sir Frederic Faſhion.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: This is no place, my Lord: we'll ſettle this buſineſs to-morrow—To-morrow, my Lord—To-morrow—

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Damnation!—Torture!—To-morrow?—He has ſome concealed meaning—A thouſand little circumſtances tell me, ſome miſchief is brooding—I could not have believed Lady Morden ſo confirmed, ſo far gone, in guilt.—The behaviour of them all, their dark alluſions, their ſarcaſms, pointed at me, convince me, they are acting in conjunction, to hold me up—How now, ſirrah! What do you ſtand gaping at?—How durſt you come between us?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why, ecod, I knew that, wi' us, i'th country, murder would have been againſt the commandements; and I had forgot that, here, in town, you have no commandements.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: This fool can ſee the exceſſes of paſſion in their true light.

sp.speaker: Gabriel
sp.p: I'm ſorry 'at I angered your Lordſhip's worſhip; becaſe as why, I wur determined to do like the reſt of my neighbours; for, ſartinly, wur a body to keep the commandements, while every body elſe is breaking them—a'd be a poor devil, indeed. [Lord Morden walks about] Belike, your Lordſhip be a bit jealouſy, like?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: How, ſirrah!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, I ſhould no' a' wondered an you wur—An I had no' been told that your Londoneers be never jealouſy, like.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Should not have wondered!—Why not, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, ecod, I munna tell!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Tell what?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, that's it—As I ſaid, I munna tell!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [puts his hand to his ſword] Speak all you know, inſtantly, or—

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [with half ſerious half ſulky reproof] Nay, nay, donna be in a paſſion, your worſhip—I be no gooſe, you munna ſpit me.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Speak, I ſay—I'll have your ſecret, or your ſoul.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ecod, I believe, your worſhip will be puzzled to find either—Tho' that Sir Frederic be an old fox—A's uſed to ſteal chicken.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Be explicit; what has he done?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Done—Oh!—A's—

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Promiſed me a place!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Zounds!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: And, moreover, a' ga' me a purſe; which is better ſtill: for, your worſhip's grace do know that, an egg, in hand, is better nur a hen, in expectation.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Suppoſe, ſirrah, I give you my purſe, too.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, ecod, an you gi' it me—I b'lieve, I ſhall—I ſhall take it.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: There, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Thank your worſhip's Lordſhip.— [Gabriel puts up the purſe, and walks leiſurely into Lady Morden's Dreſſing-Room.]

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [following Gabriel] Why, hark you, ſirrah!—Come back!—Why, raſcal!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: [calling] St! My Lord! My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [looking back to Harriet, and then recollecting Gabriel] Aſtoniſhing effrontery!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [returning] Oh! Madam, I am diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Have patience, but for one quarter of an hour, and I hope to rid you of all your fears, and inflict that puniſhment, on the author of them, which he dreads moſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: How, Madam?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: By expoſing him; making him what he delights to make others, a ſubject of laughter and contempt.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Which way, Madam?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: We may be overheard; ſtep with me into the antichamber, and I'll inform you.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [peeping after Lord Morden and Harriet, and then calling] Sir Frederic!—Sir Frederic!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Well, what's the matter? How cameſt thou off with his Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Off? Ecod, I—I wiſh you may come off as well.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees.—Why, mun, there be the bailiffs, below!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Bailiffs!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees—Sent by the Iriſh gentleman, lady I mean, a'ter your worſhip!—Ecod, hur is detarmined to ha' you, ſafe!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: The Devil! What's to be done!—Is ſhe with them?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: No; hur be come back, and is gone into the antichamber, wi' my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: And has not ſeen them?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Likely not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Here, quick, change clothes with me, and tell them you are Sir Frederic Faſhion.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Me!—Ecod, thank you for that—No, no—I would na' be in your coat, for fifty pound!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Fool! they durſt not detain you.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I'll take care they ſhan't.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: S'death! What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ecod—Suppoſe—Suppoſe I wur to go, and tell the Iriſh gentleman ſomebody wanted hur; and ſo make 'em arreſt ſhe?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha! Exquiſite fellow! I conceive—Away, ſend her inſtantly!

div.head: SCENE XII. SIR FREDERIC, TWO BAILIFFS.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Is your name Sir Frederic Faſhion, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No, Sir; but Sir Frederic will be here, directly; if you have any buſineſs with him.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: [aſide to his companion] Have your handkerchief ready, ſhould he make any noiſe, for fear of a reſcue—This is a very ſerious affair. [to Sir Frederic] Pray, Sir, what kind of perſon is Sir Frederic?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Um—a handſome—agreeable little gentleman, and very young.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: May I aſk, Sir, how he is dreſſed?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [aſide] Gad! well remember'd.— [to the bailiffs] Dreſſed, oh! he is dreſſed for—for the maſquerade—Here he comes. [the Bailiffs retire a little upon the watch.]

div.head: SCENE XIII. SIR FREDERIC, BAILIFFS, HARRIET.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [to Harriet] Well, Sir Frederic! Ha, ha, ha! How goes your ſcheme.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh, ho!—Faidth, and are you ſo jocular?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I have been thinking this is a dangerous buſineſs, and would adviſe you not to give the girl that contract—It may bring you into trouble.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: [aſide to his companion] You hear!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh! Faidth, and ſhe has it ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: [advances] Sir Frederic Faſhion [touches Harriet on the ſhoulder], you are my priſoner, Sir,—I have a ſpecial writ againſt you.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Againſt me!—Arrah, frind, but you are making a bit of a bull here.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: We know what we are about, Sir; my carriage is below; you ſhall be treated like a gentleman; but we muſt beg you to go with us, inſtantly, and without noiſe.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: [alarmed and forgetting the brogue] I tell you, friend, you miſtake the perſon.

div.head: SCENE XIV. SIR FREDERIC, HARRIET, BAILIFFS, GABRIEL.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [goes up to Harriet] Here, Sir Frederic; here be a card, from Colonel Caſtoff, wi' his compliments.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Sirrah! Me!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [with pretended aſtoniſhment] Ees, to be ſure!

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Sir, we muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: This is a concerted trick—Here— [as ſoon as Harriet begins to call, the bailiffs clap the handkerchief over her mouth, and hurry off with her.]

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Did not I do it rarely?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Do!—I could wonder and worſhip thee! In half a year, thou would'ſt make an aſs of Machiavel!—Oh that I could but retrieve that curſed contract.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I do think I could get it.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ay!—Nay, I do, almoſt, begin to believe in miracles! Which way?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: No matter for that—What will you gi' me?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Whatever thou canſt wiſh—A hundred guineas—

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: And the place in the Exciſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Any thing, every thing!—Run, try, fly!—Think, ſucceed, and I'll make an Emperor of thee!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees—I'll be Emperor of Exciſe-men.

div.head: SCENE XVI. SIR FREDERIC, MRS. MODELY, EMILY.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: The ſhrewdneſs, and abilities, of this fellow are amazing!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: [entering] Yes, my ſweet little Emily, the greateſt beauty in London would be envied, had ſhe made ſuch a conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Ah!—▪You ſay ſo.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Say! Why, to-morrow morning, the whole town will be in a flame!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, that will be pure!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Frederic—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [runs to Emily] My life! My ſoul! My tranſport!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [to Mrs. Modely] What ſweet words!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: You are very much obliged to me, I aſſure you.—I have been ſpeaking to my ſweet, dear, little Emily, here, in your behalf.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Then, Madam, I am, inexpreſſibly, obliged to you!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Modely is very much your friend, and very much my friend—A'n't you, Mrs. Modely?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Yes, my little dear; I am, indeed, very much your friend: and, if I had not the beſt opinion in the world of Sir Frederic, would not have ſpoken as I have.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, Sir Frederic, have you ordered the chaiſe and four?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [pretending to be afraid Mrs. Modely ſhould overhear]. Yes!—Huſh!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Nay, you may ſay any thing before Mrs. Modely. I have told her all; for, you know, ſhe is my friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir Frederic; be aſſured, I will not betray any ſecret, the keeping of which will make my dear Emily ſo happy!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, we ſhall be ſo happy!—You know, Sir Frederic, you ſwear to marry me.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Solemnly! [all through the ſcene he looks anxiouſly round, at intervals, fearful of being ſurpriſed.]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, but, ſwear it again; now, before Mrs. Modely.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: By all the ſaints!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Saints! Pſhaw! You ſhould ſwear by—by my bright eyes, that dim the ſtars.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Oh! By thoſe bright eyes, that dim the blazing Sun.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And—and, my beauties, that eclipſe the bluſhing Moon!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ay, by thoſe, and all your burning charms, I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: To marry me, the moment we come to Scotland?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: The moment we come to Scotland.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And, if we are purſued—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: To fight for you! Die for you!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh! That will be delightful!—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [aſide] The Devil it will!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Come, let us ſet off!—My bandbox is ready!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: That is impoſſible, my angel!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Impoſſible?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I have not ordered the chaiſe, till ten o'clock.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh dear! What, two whole hours longer!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: They are two ages, I grant— [looking round] Forgive my fears, my deareſ Emily; but, tho' the pleaſure of your company is the moſt precious thing on earth—a—a—yet—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: What, you want me gone?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Rather than you ſhould think ſo unkindly, I will run the hazard of being ſurpriſed, and eternally ſeparated from you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Will you! I am ſure you don't love me then—However, I'll go.—You will be ſure to be ready, the moment the clock ſtrikes ten.

div.head: SCENE XVII. SIR FREDERIC, MRS. MODELY.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Time is precious—Here have been ſuch plots, againſt me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Plots!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Oh! I have eſcaped Scylla and Charybdis! But wind and tide are, now, both with me—Lady Morden is to meet me, here, in half an hour. Thro' that door is her chamber.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Oh, you vile creature!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What prude, to-morrow, will dare pretend that woman, and education, are a match for man, and nature?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: And ſo you will perſiſt in your wickedneſs, in ſpite of my perſuaſions!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Lady Morden has, ſtill, all the rhodomontade of love, in her brain—Thinks of nothing but cooing-conſtancy, and eternal raptures!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Simple woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Except, indeed, tormenting her huſband; which ſeems to give the ſin a double ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Or ſhe would be no wife!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: So, as ſoon as I am gone off with Emily, I will have a conſolatory epiſtle delivered to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Compaſſionate toad!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Here it is, ready written; and, if I don't flatter myſelf, a maſter-piece.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Let me ſee! Let me ſee!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No, you ſhall hear. [reads] Dear Madam, Tho' you are an angel, if there are other angels, am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

p.q: If man is naturally inconſtant, and if I am a man—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

p.q: If nature has made variety the higheſt enjoyment—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

p.q: If, ſince happineſs is the purſuit of us all, I am happy as often as I can—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

p.q: Farewell, Madam; circumſtances, as you will find, force me, thus ſuddenly, from your arms, in which, I own, I found heaven centered: but, if you ſhould call me cruel, perjured, and ungrateful, becauſe I act naturally, and therefore rationally—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not!—Well, as I live, this is a maſter-ſtroke! Perfectly as I thought I knew you, you have aſtoniſhed me!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Yes; 'tis the true Socratic mode—But, now, my dear Mrs. Modely, go you to Emily, prevent her diſturbing us, and keep her in readineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Well! remember, every thing is at ſtake, and be yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Fear me not; that preſcience, which, they ſay, is the forerunner of all great events, gives me a happy aſſurance of ſucceſs: a confidence, that makes ſucceſs certain.

sp.speaker: General Burland.
sp.p: I Cannot keep from this houſe!—There is a foreboding of miſchief, which haunts, and perturbs, my imagination!—And, I fear, with reaſon!—The malignant joy, the ſmothered exult, the obſcure, ironical, ſatire, which ran through the diſcourſe of that Sir Frederic, were not without a meaning.—I wiſh I had not conſented to let Emily ſtay—He ſneered, I remember, at the moment: nay, it ſeemed the ſneer of triumph!—I wiſh ſhe were ſafe, at my own houſe.—Poor Lady Morden!—And, is it poſſible?—Such rectitude of heart!—Such purity of ſentiment!—I wiſh Emily were at home—Should my child, my darling fall, I were a wretch indeed!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [wildly] I am miſerable! diſtracted! racked!—The thunderbolt has ſtruck before I heard it!—Oh that its exterminating power had been final! But it has maimed, and deformed, and left a full feeling of wretchedneſs!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: How now, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: General!—I am a wretch!—An irretrievable, eternal, wretch!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: What, and are you come to a ſenſe of this, now it is too late?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: There's the miſery!—The curſe is accompliſhed, and hope is fled!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: Why, ay! Such is the infatuation of folly, and vice, they will not believe vengeance has an arm, till its fatal gripe is felt!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I cannot ſupport theſe tortures!—Oh that it were poſſible!—

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: To reclaim Lady Morden.

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: What then? Another month and Sir Frederic Faſhion, or any other libertine of faſhion, might take her.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Never!—Never!—Were her affections once again mine, the ſtroke of death, only, ſhould ſeparate us!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: [with deep compaſſion] Well, my Lord, if you are, at laſt, convinced of the immenſity of your loſs—I pity you!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Oh, would you could relieve!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: Would I could!—But, you were a witneſs how ineffectual my endeavours were. However, walk with me, into the antichamber, and let us conſult what is beſt to be done.—Her principles, I fear, are ſhaken; the only rock on which virtue can ſtand ſecure.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p:
Sapped, deſtroyed!—She avows her intents! Unbluſhingly avows them! And, recapitulating my errors, my crimes, dares me to complain of, or notice, hers! Scorns and contemns me, and juſtly too, that ſuch a thing as I
ſhould pretend to repeat, or reſpect, the word virtue!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: It is what every huſband, every father of a family, muſt expect! His ſmalleſt foibles will ſtand as precedents for a ſwarm of follies; and, if he has any vices, they will propagate a hideous brood, that ſhall extirpate his name from the earth, or overwhelm it with obloquy!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [peeping after Lord Morden, and the General] Come, mun!—Your worſhip, come!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Are they gone?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Well, what haſt thou done?—Where is Harriet?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh, I ha' her ſafe.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Thou!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees, mun—For, when the Bailiffs found out a wur a woman, they wur parfitly ravenous!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: And let her go?

sp.speaker: Gabriel
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: S'death!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: But, I ſecured her.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Secured! Impoſſible! How?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, never do you mind how—I tell'ee, I ha' her ſafe.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: But where are the Bailiffs?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: In this houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: The devil they are!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees, they be—waiting for your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Death and deſtruction!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: But what o'that? I a'got the contract, mun.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Haſt thou?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees, here it is.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Precious fellow! I could worſhip thee!—Give it me.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [putting his hand behind him.] Nay, hold there!—I wunna do that.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Won't!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: No—I wunna.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Make no words, but deliver it—and, here—here is—

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, put up your paper, for I wunna part wi' mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: S'death, fellow!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, be mild tempered—ſtand where you be; for an you ſtir another ſtep, I'll call the Bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [aſide] Cunning ſcoundrel!—He has me in his power, and time preſſes.—Well, Gabriel, be faithful, and, depend on't, I'll make thee a clever fellow.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why, ecod, I think I am like a Monmouth-ſtreet coat—ready made.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Thou remembereſt the inſtructions I gave thee?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Parfitly.

sp.speaker: Sir. Frederic.
sp.p: The chaiſe is to wait, at the corner of the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Thou art to convey Emily's bandbox away, privately; and, if any queſtions are aſked, to ſay it is Lady Morden's.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Haſt thou taken care of the letter, I gave thee?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Care! Ees, ees; I a' ta'en good care on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Obſerve, thou art to deliver, it to Lady Morden, half an hour after we are departed.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Half an hour before you are departed.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Zounds! No, half an hour after, man.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh! Ees, ees; half an hour after.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Now begone.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: But—but, how will your worſhip get by the Bailiffs?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: S'death, that's true!—Is there no diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why—ees—there be a long greatcoat i'th' hall.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ay, true!—Bring it me.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, nay—I'll put it on firſt, and let 'em ſee me—ſo, then, when they ſee you, they'll think it be I—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Excellent! Where are Lord Morden, and the General?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I'th' t'other chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Unlucky! I wiſh they were any where elſe.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh!—an that be all, I'll ſoon make 'em budge.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay!—Lord, you're ſo quiſitive!—I tell you, I'll do't—I'll ſaunter thro' this door, lock it, and ſend 'em packing thro' t'other.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Thou art the prince of plotters—Away, be vigilant.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh! never do you fear me!

div.head: SCENE IV. SIR FREDERIC, LADY MORDEN.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: This fellow would outwit a whole conclave of Cardinals!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Well, Sir Frederic! here I am, you ſee; punctual to my promiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [with vaſt inſinuation, ſeeming ſincerity, and humble rapture, all through the ſcene.] Oh, Madam, how can I repay this bounty!—this condeſcenſion!—Never!—My life were a poor ſacrifice, to ſuch ſweetneſs and ſuch charms!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Sir Frederic, this is a trying, a deciſive moment! I am going to be either the moſt happy or the moſt wretched of women! You tell me, it is your wiſh, your reſolution, to be no longer that general lover, that man of the world, you have, hitherto, been thought.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Say not, dear Lady, it is either my wiſh or reſolution! Heaven can teſtify, I have not the power to be any thing, but what it ſhall pleaſe you to make me!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: I have owned to you that, the levity I have lately affected is not natural to me▪ that my heart ſighs for an acquaintance, a mate▪ that, like itſelf, is ſubject to all the ſweet emotions of ſenſibility!—Yes, it was the firſt wiſh of my ſoul to find this correſpondent heart! A heart beating with the ſame ardour, vibrating to the ſame ſenſations, panting for the ſame pleaſures, ſhrinking from the ſame pangs; pliant, yet firm; gentle, yet aſpiring; paſſionate, yet pure!—Such I once thought Lord Morden's—Should I, a ſecond time, be deceived!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I am poor in proofs of ſincerity! I have none to offer!—My former errors are preſent puniſhments! To deny or even palliate them would imply intentional deceit; and this is a moment in which I would wiſh for men and gods to be witneſſes of my truth!—I have had, I own, moſt libertine opinions of your gentle ſex; but theſe I, now, ſolemnly renounce!—Had I, before, met with a Lady Morden, I ſhould, before, have made this renunciation!—But, perhaps, the women it has been my misfortune to know deſerved, in part, the light eſteem in which I held them.—Never, till now, did I find one who could mutually inſpire ſuch paſſion and reſpect! Such agitated, burning, hopes! Such excruciating fears, or thoughts ſo ſanctified, as thoſe I, this moment, feel!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Yet, Sir Frederic, I cannot help obſerving your converſation, in ſociety, ſeems ſtill tinged with the impurity of your former libertine principles.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I own, Lady Morden, with confuſion own, I have not hitherto had the courage, or, perhaps, I have wanted ſtrength to ſtem the torrent: but, aided by you, I feel, I dare promiſe any thing!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: I confeſs, Sir Frederic, the mind finds ſome difficulty in rooting out fears, planted in it by reiterated accuſations. The ſtories the world tells of you are dreadful! And, yet, there is ſuch heartfelt conviction attends your preſent words that, to me, it is impoſſible to liſten and retain a doubt.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p:
This generous confidence tranſports me, fills me with gratitude, and inſpires
rapturous hope! [claſps her round the waiſt.] Oh, gently ſuffer me to conduct you, where love lies, in panting, breathleſs, ecſtaſy—

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: To them GABRIEL, abruptly, in a Great-coat, ſtands fixed, ſtaring.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [ſternly] How now!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [deliberately] Belike—You dunna want company?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I thought as much—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [laying hold of him] Begone, inſtantly!

sp.speaker: Gabriel
sp.p: Nay! Hands off! [throws him from him] I ſhan't ſtir, till I have delivered my meſſage.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What meſſage? What have you to ſay?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [aloud] Why the chaiſe and four be come.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [ſtill louder] The bandbox ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Infernal booby!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Miſs Emily waiting.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [violently] Begone, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Gone!—Nay, ſartinly, you would no' ha' I run away wi' her.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [with contempt] Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Lady Morden!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha!—Why, ſurely, you! The never failing victor! The fertile-brained Sir Frederic Faſhion! who knows not defeat, and who never, yet, was at a loſs for ſtratagems!
Though you are taken ſomewhat unawares, you cannot want invention!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: You'll pardon me, Madam, if I want underſtanding to comprehend your meaning.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Indeed!—Well, if you are ſo very dull of apprehenſion—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Oh!—Do you recollect—this letter?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: How!—Faithleſs fiend! [goes to aſſault Gabriel, who throws back his great-coat and appears dreſſed as a gentleman.]

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Keep off, or dread the chaſtiſement I am prompted, inſtantaneouſly, to inflict!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Chaſtiſement!—What is this?—Who are you?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: A man!—You are—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, brother!—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Brother!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Gabriel Wilmot; whoſe head is ſo full of the nonſenſe of friendſhip, honour, and honeſty!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I'll be revenged, however.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: To them LORD MORDEN and GENERAL

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Turn, wretch, and receive your puniſhment from this arm! [Sir Frederic turns on Lord Morden.]

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: [beating down their ſwords] Oh, for ſhame!—Look to the Lady—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Oh, General!—Oh, my Lord! [runs to Lord Morden and falls on his neck.]

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: My life! My ecſtaſy! My ſaviour!

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: To them MRS. MODELY and EMILY.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Bleſs me, what uproar—Hey day!— [aſide] So, ſo! Here is a very pretty denouement to our plot, indeed!— [aloud] I ſee, good folks, you are all embroiled here; and, as it is a very diſagreeable thing to be preſent at family diſputes, I'll— [is going; the General plants himſelf againſt the door]

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, ſtay, and receive the compliments of the company—Mine, and your friend Emily's, in particular.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Oh, with pleaſure!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Mr. Wilmot! My beſt brother!—Though you have, in part, acquainted me with what is paſt, yet, it is ſo ſudden—And you! my deareſt Lady! To find you ſtill the ſame is joy unſpeakable!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: The taſk of making you ſuppoſe I had effectually become what I ſeemed, was, indeed, moſt painful; but the loſs of your affection were not pain! 'Twere horror!—I told you my paſſion was too permanent to be ſhaken—Ah! how could you imagine I meant another? Or think it poſſible I ever could forget that chaſte, that ardent, that eternal, love, I have ſo repeatedly vowed?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Oh for words!—I am all love! gratitude! rapture! and amazement!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: And ſo is Sir Frederic, apparently—Nay, even you, Madam, ſeem a little ſurpriſed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Me! Oh dear, no.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [to Sir Frederic] Dear Sir, though you are a deep and excellent plotter, if there have been counterplots—am I to blame? [curtſies.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: [with affected candour] Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: If man is ſometimes vain, preſumptuous, and unprincipled, and if you are a man—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wilmot.
sp.p: If I aſſumed a mean diſguiſe, that I might aid a ſiſter, to detect, and expoſe, the mean machinations of Seduction—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: If, following the advice of this dear Lady [to Lady Morden] ſimplicity has made cunning outwit itſelf—am I to blame? [curtſying firſt to Sir Frederic, and then to Mrs. Modely.]

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: [with vaſt pleaſure] Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: If, ſince happineſs is the purſuit of us all, I wiſh to be as happy as poſſible— [moſt affectionately taking Lord Morden's hand] am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [with affected eaſe] Certainly not—So, the catechiſm being ended, the ſcholars may depart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wilmot.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Wilmot.
sp.p: You forget the bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Beſides, Sir Frederic, before you go, you muſt give me leave to introduce you to—

div.head: SCENE THE LAST.
div.stage: To them HARRIET in woman's clothes preſented by Lady Morden.
div.p: —This Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Harriet!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—that Harriet, whom, hearing ſhe had happineſs in view, and proportioning your ideal triumph to the weight of miſery you might entail, you raiſed heaven and earth to bring to wretchedneſs, and ruin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Upon my honour, you—you are a ſad man, Sir Frederic!—A very ſad man!
sp.stage: [The company by their looks ſhew they underſtand Mrs. Modely's real character.]

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But your vanity is humbled—you, now, ſtand detected; and, inſtead of envied, you will be ſneered at by the depraved, pitied by the good, and, henceforth, avoided by the credulous young creatures you, ſo manfully, have delighted to involve in guilt, and deſtruction!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: A very dangerous man, indeed, Sir Frederic!

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: [ironically] Ay! beware of him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Oh! I—I will!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the finger of ſcorn points where it ought: you are expoſed, and my reſentment is appeaſed.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Then, Madam—the—the contract—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
There it is, Sir. [returns it] I never meant to make any other uſe of it than what has
been better effected, by different means. [curtſying to Lady Morden and Mr. Wilmot.]

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Madam!—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: No thanks, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: No; they would ſit a little awkwardly.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: And now, Sir Frederic, if, after this leſſon, you ſhould ſtill retain your former principles, and practices, and, hereafter, receive a ſtill ſeverer puniſhment, I hope you will acknowledge—we are not to blame.

lg.l: IN former times—'tis long ago, I own—
Man, ſeated on the haughty huſband's throne,
The wife by ſuch abſurd reſtraints enclos'd,
Not one gallant had ſhe—as he ſuppos'd:
But, modeſt, meek, his jealous doubts appeas'd,
And ſooth'd her lord and maſter—when ſhe pleas'd.
Then, women led ſuch exemplary lives,
Daughters, almoſt, as humble were—a—as wives!
"A ſavage Salick law the men maintain'd;
"O monſtrous! We were ſlaves! and huſband's reign'd."—
Strange were theſe cuſtoms, obſolete; but we
Conſolidate our cuſtoms—and, you ſee,
Such wiſe deſigns no oppoſition find:
A fair free trade is good for all mankind.
The lib'ral ſpirit of our lib'ral beauties
Has quite annull d prohibitory duties.
The Ciciſbeo, and the chere amie,
On the broad baſe of reciprocity,
Are exports now, and imports, duty free.
As for this Lady Morden's motley merit,
With her half-ancient, her half-modern ſpirit,
You'll imitate the part you moſt approve;
Her modiſh licence, or her maukiſh love!
Of that no more—The ſubject of my ſpeech,
The doctrine I came, purpoſely, to teach,
(Nay, look not low'ring, man of mighty ſenſe)
Is rival woman's ſuper-eminence—*
"Yes, we have proofs where wit, where taſte combin'
"To deck, with blended charms, the female mind.
"Say, ſhall not we, with conſcious pride, proclaim
"A female critic rais'd—ev'n Shakeſpear's Fame!
"Yes, lordly man—look ſurly if you pleaſe,
"But women beat you out and out, with eaſe!
"In tales of fancy, tenderneſs, diſtreſs,
"If you dare doubt us—ſtudy The Receſs.
"While Reaſon guides the clue, in Fancy's maze.
"In tragedy our triumph all atteſt;
"Your tears the genuine proof who acts the beſt—
"In comedy—But hold—I dread to ſay
"How much, of late, ev'n there, you've loſt the day."
No, I'll not humble your proud ſex ſo far,
Till you no more remember—SUCH THINGS ARE.
Gladly our author owns, all this is true;
Nor thinks he's robb'd, when others have their due:
Yet, owning, hopes you've kindly heard his cauſe;
Hopes to participate your juſt applauſe.
And, ſhould your hands ſome grateful wreath combine,
And ſhould that wreath his anxious brow entwine,
The prize moſt precious mem'ry holds in ſtore,

It there ſhall bloom—'till mem'ry is no more!
* The verſes, between inverted commas, were requeſted from, and written by, a gentleman whoſe literary abilities are great, and well known; and the following were, conſequently, omitted.
Is rival woman's ſuper-eminence
In wit, as well as beauty! Proofs I could
But will not cite, to make th' aſſertion good.
Why ſhould I ſpeak, what's known to Fame and you,
Young André's woes; the wrongs of old Peru?
Why the Belle's Stratagem, or Percy name;
Or ſweet Cecilia's never ending fame?
Our comic, or our tragic, triumphs quote;
Or tell how Siddons acted, Burney wrote?
No, I'll not humble, &c.
